"The only wrong way to fish is keeping more than you need.

"
".

"

"Using the right tool makes any job easier.

"
"That having been said, depending on the job, deciding on what the right tool is isn't always obvious." "I'll try and categorize a few ways of fishing, with what seems to me to be the minimum gear to take with you that will allow you to fish until you want to stop fishing.

"
"Line 
" "Choosing the correct line to use is important. Have an idea of what type of fish you plan on trying to catch, and what the typical size range of those fish is. While line material technology is constantly being improved on, generally speaking, look for a line weight that barely meets or exceeds the size of the fish you will probably be encountering. This will allow for the least line visibility - you don't want fish to notice it - and greatest sensitivity. The rod you choose also matters when it comes to the size range of the line you should use. Larger weight lines tend to reduce the sensitivity, and increase the visibility, among other aspects. Bring a spare spool with you.

"
"Hooks 
" "Just like with the thought behind line; bigger is not necessarily better. Once again, it depends on the type of fish you are fishing for, but keeping the hook smaller is a good idea for a few reasons:
" "- the fish won't be able to see it as well
" "- the fish will actually be able to get hooked
" "- you won't overwhelm the bait you are using

" "You also want to pick the right style of hook. Hooks come in many shapes and styles - too many for me to cover all of them. In general, the aspects that they are specialized for are:
" "1) what type of bait you are using
" "2) how you plan on fishing with it; i.e. with a bobber, trolling, etc.

"
"Sinkers 
 Are you fishing for surface-focused fish? If not, you most definitely need a way to get your bait down to the fish you are targeting, and that's where a sinker comes into play. Weigh things down.
 Depending on if you are using a bobber, "bouncing the bottom", trolling, or trying to keep your bait anchored in one place, you will need to look at a different type of sinker.


A Rod 
 When I say 'rod', I mean this in the most basic sense; something for you to hold in order to safely apply pressure to the line in order to bring any fish out of the water, and successfully into your possession! This could be something as simple as a cane pole, but probably something made out of graphite, meant to work with a reel. What you want out of the rod you choose is a combination of flexibility, sensitivity, and size that is appropriate for *how* you are going to fish, and what type of fish you anticipate catching.


A Reel 
 This is a device that serves safely store the line you are using, in such a way to protect it from damage, and allow it to be dynamically lengthened or shortened when trying to catch fish. Reels (and rods) can be very expensive, and depending on the type of fishing you are planning on doing, may require careful care. Essentially - as is the trend with a number of pieces of gear - you want to pick a reel that is the right size and style for how you are trying to fish and what you are fishing for.


Bait
 Depending on what you are trying to catch, there are so many different things you can fish with - both live and inanimate - that it's impossible for me to cover this topic completely. What you need to use is simply something to put on the other end of the line from you, that you think a fish will want to put into its mouth.


Pliers and/or Hemostats 
 - The mouths of fish can be very tough, and once a hook is embedded, they can be difficult to remove - especially since most hooks are barbed.
 - The fish could have swallowed the hook further down than you can grab, and having a thin tool to reach down in a fish mouth can be handy.
 - Some fish have sharp teeth and/or strong jaws that you don't want to put your fingers anywhere close to.


Clippers or a Knife (cutting tool) 
 Most of the reasons for having a cutting tool at hand have to do with the line. Mainly it's:
 - after tying a knot
 - if a fish completely swallows the bait
 - if you get hopelessly snagged
 - if a giant knot forms in the middle of your line


Towel
 Always remember to bring a towel. "

"Keeping your line in the water.\n\n"
"Just like with most things in this world, fishing gear will only last as long as it is cared for appropriately."
